required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Predictive Factors for a Clinical Diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome in a Large Cohort of Young Adults.
clinical_study.official_title: Predictive Factors for a Clinical Diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome in a Large Cohort of 440,822 Young Adults.

brief_summary.textblock: The prevalence of IBS in the community has been reported in numerous cross-sectional surveys. However, less is known about the incidence of IBS ,mainly due to its slow development and to patients under-reporting. Furthermore, only one study has analyzed data concerning potential risk factors for the diagnosis of IBS. The investigators will examine the incidence of IBS in a large cohort of young adults and will look at the association of socioeconomic, anthropometric and occupational factors with IBS incidence.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of clinical diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome
primary_outcome.description: New diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome during this priod

secondary_outcome.measure: predictive factors for the clinical diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome
secondary_outcome.description: Anthropometric and demographic factors predictive for the clinicaldiagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome including gender, body mass index, ethnicity , type of service

arm_group.description: All new cases of clinical diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome

study_pop.textblock: The study population will consist of Israeli men and women aged 18-39 years who served in active military service (mandatory and career service) between the years 2005-2011

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All Israeli men and women
- aged 18-39 years
- served in active military service (mandatory and career service) between the years 2005-2011
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of celiac disease
- Inflammatory bowel disease
- Cancer in the digestive system

clinical_study.keyword: Deterioration in the severity of irritable bowel syndrome
